Dear Ms. Stevens:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
August 6, 2019. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should
be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the ISEP
and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter
and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or ISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 An explanation why previous corrective action plans have not
obtained and maintained compliance for rules found in repeat
noncompliance.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R400.12312 Foster parent training.
(4) At least 1 adult member of the household shall have training
in an maintain a current certification in first aid from the
American Heart Association or the American Red Cross or other
institution approved by the Department.
One of eight open foster home records reviewed showed the
foster parent’s first aid training had expired 9/30/18.
Repeat Violation, Interim 2018.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(1) An agency shall do all of the following when anyone in the
agency receives information that relates to possible
noncompliance with any foster home rule:
(a) Submit a special investigation record to the department's
licensing authority within 5 working days in the manner
prescribed by the department.
One of five special evaluations reviewed showed the special
investigation record was submitted to the department more than
five days after the 5/14/19 complaint intake date.
R400.12327 Special evaluation.
(1) An agency shall do all of the following when anyone in the
agency receives information that relates to possible
noncompliance with any foster home rule:
(c) Conduct a thorough investigation including all necessary
collateral contacts.
One of five special evaluations reviewed did not show clear
documentation that all persons in home, or the therapist who
was referred to were interviewed. Nor what relevant information
the agency’s licensing supervisor reported related to the
complaint since an interview with the licensing supervisor was
stated as part of the basis for concluding no rule
noncompliance.
4

R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(3) An agency shall complete a special evaluation within 45
calendar days after receipt of the information. If additional time
is required, then the agency shall inform the foster parent, in
writing, of the basis for the extension and the expected length of
the extension. The total time for the completion of the
investigation shall not exceed 90 calendar days without written
approval from the chief administrator or his or her designee.
Two of five special evaluations reviewed did not show
compliance:
 One record showed a 45-day letter dated 3/11/19, was
four days late per the complaint’s 1/21/19 intake date.
 A second record did not show documentation of a 45-day
letter due by 2/19/19 per the 1/5/19 date of intake. Nor a
90-day chief administrator’s written approval, since
completion of the special evaluation went beyond 90
days per contacts listed in the report.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an
agency shall complete a written report that includes all of the
following information:
(e) Findings of fact based upon the evaluation.
Five of five special evaluations reviewed did not show
documentation of the worker’s analysis/summation as to how
the worker arrived at conclusions of compliance or
noncompliance as based on finding of facts in the special
evaluation.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(6) An agency shall do all of the following:
(a) Provide the foster parent with a copy of the report
required by subrule (5) of this rule within 10 calendar days of its
completion.
Four of five special evaluations reviewed did not show
documentation that the foster parent was provided a copy of the
report in 10 calendar days.
5

(b) Inform the foster parent, in writing, that he or she has a right
to have his or her written response included as an attachment to
the report required by subrule (5) of this rule.
Four of five special evaluations reviewed did not show
documentation that the foster parent was informed, in writing,
that he or she has a right to have his or her written response
attached to the report.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(6) An agency shall do all of the following:
(c) Provide a copy of the report to any social services worker
that has children placed in the home.
Five of five special evaluations reviewed did not show
documentation that the social services worker was provided a
copy of the report.
R400.12404 Placement.
(7) An agency shall document, in the child's record, within 7
calendar days after placement, the information specified in R
400.12417(1) and all of the following information:
(g) Documentation of the child’s preparation for placement.
One of eight open child records reviewed did not show
documentation of the child’s preparation for placement as
required by the rule.
Repeat Violation, Interim 2018, Renewal 2017, Interim 2016.
R400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all of the following in the child's
record before a change of placement occurs:
(e) Replacement preparation, regardless of the child's age,
appropriate to the child's capacity to understand, which includes
an explanation to all relevant parties as to why the change is
necessary.
One of eight open child records reviewed did not show
documentation of the child’s preparation related the child’s
replacement on 11/9/19.
Four of six closed child records reviewed did not show
documentation of the child’s preparation related to the change.

R400.12405 Change of placement.
(5) If an agency is no longer providing services to the child in a
foster home, then both of the following shall be documented
before a change in placement:
(a) A summary of the services provided during care up to the
time of the change in placement and the needs that remain to
be met.
(b) Provision for any continuing services.
Four of six closed child records reviewed did not show
documentation of (a) and (b) as required by the rule. A DHS-69
which may have also contained this information was either not
documented or the DHS-69 did not address the information.
Repeat Violation Interim, 2018.
R400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(d) Current immunizations for each child as required by
section 5111 of 1978 PA 368, MCL 333.5111. All of the
following apply:
(i) A statement from a parent or licensed medical authority
which indicates that immunizations are current or
contraindicated is sufficient documentation of immunizations.
(ii) A copy of a waiver addressed to the department of
community health signed by the parent stating immunizations
are not being administered due to religious, medical, or other
reasons is sufficient documentation of immunizations.
(iii) If documentation of immunization or a copy of the
waiver is unavailable, then immunizations shall begin within 30
calendar days of placement.
Two of eight open child records reviewed showed the child’s
DTp/DTaP/Td/Tdap was overdue as of 3/18/19 and 8/6/19
respectively. One of these children’s Hepatitis A immunization
was also overdue, as of 2/8/19.
A statement from a parent or medical authority, or waiver as
outline in (ii) was not documented indicating these
immunizations were current, contraindicated or not being
administered due to religious, medical or other reasons.
7

(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a

(f) The provision of a dental examination and any treatment

(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child

(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at

R400.12504 Eligibility requirements.
(2) All of the following shall be in the case record before a youth
is placed in independent living:
(a) How the youth meets the eligibility requirements for the
specific program the youth is being placed into.
(b) The basis for concluding that a youth exhibits self-care

(d) The availability of specific and relevant resources that

(f)Proof that financial support to meet the youth’s housing,

R400.12505 Supervision.
(2) An agency shall provide the following minimum supervision:
(a)Face-to-face contact between the social service worker and

One of three open independent living youth records reviewed

R400.12509 Independent living record.
(3) The case record shall contain all of the following information

(g) Current documentation of financial support sufficient to meet

(1) There shall be a mutually agreed upon contract between the

(a) The responsibility of the agency and the youth.
(b) A plan for education or work.
(c) An agreement for the youth to meet with the worker at least
one time per calendar month.
(d) The location where the youth is living.
One of three open independent living youth records reviewed
did not show documentation of (a)-(d) as required by the rule.
Repeat Violation related to (a), Renewal 2017.
R400.12510 Independent living contract.
(2) The agreement shall be signed and dated by the youth and
the social service worker. The contract shall be reviewed and
10

updated at least once every 90 calendar days and a copy
provided the youth.
One of three open independent living youth records reviewed

R400.12511 Termination.
(2) An agency shall ensure and document that each youth who

(b) A birth certificate.
(c) A social security card.
(d) The youth’s fund and personal property.

Three of three records did not show documentation of

ISEP 6.18 Relative Foster Parent Licensing, Timeliness (Commitment
54)
Relative foster parents must be licensed within 180 days of
the date of placement.

ISEP 6.30 Supervisory Oversight (Commitment 66).
Supervisors shall meet at least monthly with each assigned
worker to review the status and progress of each case on
the worker’s caseload. Supervisors shall review and approve
each service plan. The plan can be approved only after the
supervisor has a face-to-face meeting with the worker, which
can be the monthly meeting

(c) Service plans shall be signed by the caseworker, the

ISEP 6.42 Visits, Between Siblings (Commitment 78).
(a) DHHS shall ensure that children in foster care who have
siblings in custody with whom they are not placed shall have at
least monthly visits with their siblings who are placed elsewhere
in DHHS foster care custody. Exceptions to this requirement
are cases in which:
(1) the visit may be harmful to one or more of the siblings;
(2) the sibling is placed out of state in compliance with the
Interstate Compact on Placement of Children;
(3) the distance between the children's placements is more than
50 miles and the child is placed with a relative; or
(4) one of the siblings is above the age of 16 and refuses such
visits.

(a) At the time the child is placed or re-placed, the foster care

Policy FOM 722- Foster Care Action Summary.
09C
The Foster Care/Juvenile Justice (FC/JJ) Action Summary,
DHS-69 (RFF 69), is used whenever there is “action” on a case.
The foster care action summary is generated from SWSS FAJ.
The DHS worker must complete the DHS-69, Action Summary
(RFF 69) in SWSS. Child placing agencies will continue to use
the DHS-69, Action Summary template. This form also serves
as notice to the courts of changes in placements, parent's living
situation and the FC worker/agency, as identifying information is
indicated. The FC/JJ action summary meets licensing
requirements for replacement documentation (See FOM 722-
03) and in most cases, agency transfer and case closing
summary (see below). The FC/JJ action summary must also be
used for foster care transfer to adoption.
Which Cases/ When What does this mean
All foster care cases where there is:
1. A replacement.
2. Termination from foster care placement.

Security Awareness Training for Fingerprint Base Criminal

Security Awareness Training (SAT) is required for authorized
personnel who have been granted access to fingerprint-based

provides information on what fingerprint based CHRI is, who
has access, how to ensure this information remains secure both
physically an electronically, and how you can use this
information appropriately.
All non-contracted and governmental CPA employees,
subcontractors, subcontractor’s employees or volunteers who
